Clarence Thomas

Clarence Thomas is an American lawyer and jurist serving as an associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States since 1991. He is the second African American to serve on the Court, after Thurgood Marshall, and has been a conservative presence on the bench for over three decades.

Early life

Thomas was born on June 23, 1948, in Pin Point, Georgia, to M.C. Thomas and Leola Williams Thomas. He was the second of three children, and his family lived in a small, rural community near Savannah, Georgia. Thomas's early life was marked by poverty and hardship, but his parents instilled in him a strong sense of values and a commitment to education.

College of the Holy Cross and Yale Law School

Thomas attended St. Pius X High School in Atlanta, Georgia, where he excelled academically and was an outstanding football player. He was recruited by several colleges, but chose to attend the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, Massachusetts. Thomas graduated from Holy Cross in 1971, with a degree in English literature. He then attended Yale Law School, where he earned his Juris Doctor (J.D.) degree in 1974.

Early legal career

Thomas's early legal career was marked by a series of high-profile jobs. He worked as a law clerk for Judge Howard W. Cannon of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, and later as an associate at the law firm of Covington & Burling. Thomas also worked as a senior trial attorney for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), where he was involved in several high-profile cases.

District of Columbia Court of Appeals

In 1981, Thomas was appointed as an assistant secretary for civil rights at the U.S. Department of Education. He served in this position for two years, before being appointed as a member of the U.S. Sentencing Commission. Thomas was also a visiting scholar at the American Enterprise Institute (AEI) in 1987, where he wrote extensively on issues related to civil rights and law.

Nomination to the Supreme Court

In 1990, President George H.W. Bush nominated Thomas to the Supreme Court, to fill the seat vacated by Justice Thurgood Marshall. Thomas's nomination was contentious, due to allegations made by Anita Hill, a former colleague at the EEOC.

Anita Hill accusations

Hill alleged that Thomas had made unwanted advances towards her, and had spoken about pornography in a workplace setting. Thomas denied the allegations, and his nomination was eventually confirmed by the Senate in a narrow vote.

Second hearing

The Senate held a second hearing to investigate the allegations, but no additional evidence was presented, and Thomas's nomination was eventually confirmed.

Senate votes

The Senate voted on Thomas's nomination on October 15, 1991. The final vote was 52-48, with several Democrats voting in favor of confirmation.

Supreme Court of the United States

Thomas has served on the Supreme Court for over three decades, and has been a conservative presence on the bench. He has written several influential opinions, including United States v. Lopez (1995), which established the authority of Congress to regulate interstate commerce.

Government powers and legal structure

Thomas has written extensively on issues related to government powers and the legal structure of the United States. He has argued that the Constitution grants broad powers to the federal government, and has been critical of Supreme Court decisions that limit those powers.

Court precedent

Thomas has been critical of the doctrine of stare decisis, which holds that lower courts must follow the decisions of higher courts. He has argued that the Supreme Court should revisit earlier decisions that are no longer consistent with the Constitution.

Executive power

Thomas has been a strong supporter of executive power, and has argued that the President has broad authority to take action in the absence of legislative authority. He has been critical of the Supreme Court's decision in Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Sawyer (1952), which limited the President's power to take action in the absence of legislative authority.

Federalism and states' rights

Thomas has been a strong supporter of federalism and states' rights, and has argued that the Constitution grants broad powers to the states. He has been critical of Supreme Court decisions that limit the powers of the states, such as Roe v. Wade (1973).

Individual rights

Thomas has written extensively on issues related to individual rights, including free speech, gun rights, and the right to privacy.

First Amendment

Thomas has been a strong supporter of the First Amendment, and has argued that it grants broad protections for free speech and assembly. He has been critical of Supreme Court decisions that limit those protections, such as United States v. Stevens (2010).

Second Amendment

Thomas has been a strong supporter of the Second Amendment, and has argued that it grants an individual right to bear arms. He has been critical of Supreme Court decisions that limit that right, such as Heller v. District of Columbia (2008).

Fourth Amendment

Thomas has been critical of the Fourth Amendment, and has argued that it grants broad powers to the police to search and seize property. He has been critical of Supreme Court decisions that limit those powers, such as Riley v. California (2014).

Sixth Amendment

Thomas has been a strong supporter of the Sixth Amendment, and has argued that it grants broad protections for the right to a fair trial. He has been critical of Supreme Court decisions that limit those protections, such as Crawford v. Washington (2004).

Eighth Amendment

Thomas has been a strong supporter of the Eighth Amendment, and has argued that it grants broad protections against cruel and unusual punishment. He has been critical of Supreme Court decisions that limit those protections, such as Graham v. Florida (2010).

Fourteenth Amendment

Thomas has been a strong supporter of the Fourteenth Amendment, and has argued that it grants broad protections for individual rights. He has been critical of Supreme Court decisions that limit those protections, such as Roe v. Wade (1973).

Abortion and family planning

Thomas has been a strong opponent of abortion and family planning, and has argued that the Constitution does not grant a right to abortion. He has been critical of Supreme Court decisions that have protected that right, such as Planned Parenthood v. Casey (1992).

LGBTQ rights

Thomas has been a strong opponent of LGBTQ rights, and has argued that the Constitution does not grant a right to same-sex marriage. He has been critical of Supreme Court decisions that have protected those rights, such as Obergefell v. Hodges (2015).

Oral arguments

Thomas has been a vocal advocate for oral arguments, and has argued that they provide a critical check on the power of the judiciary. He has been critical of Supreme Court decisions that have limited the availability of oral arguments.

Personal life

Thomas is married to Virginia Thomas, and has two children, Jamal and Gwendolyn. Thomas is a devout Catholic, and has been involved in several charitable organizations.

Family

Thomas's family has been the subject of several media reports, including a profile in The New York Times. Thomas's wife, Virginia, has been involved in several high-profile cases, including the Anita Hill hearings.

Religion

Thomas is a devout Catholic, and has spoken publicly about the importance of his faith. He has been involved in several charitable organizations, including the Catholic Legal Immigration Network.

Literary influences

Thomas has cited several literary influences, including Ralph Ellison and James Baldwin. He has spoken publicly about the importance of literature in shaping his views on justice and equality.

Moira Smith allegations

In 2010, a former colleague of Thomas's alleged that he had made unwanted advances towards her. Thomas denied the allegations, and no further action was taken.

Nondisclosure of finances

In 2011, it was reported that Thomas had failed to disclose his financial holdings, as required by law. Thomas denied any wrongdoing, and eventually disclosed his holdings.

Honors and recognition

Thomas has been awarded several honors and recognitions, including the American Bar Association's Thurgood Marshall Award and the Catholic Legal Immigration Network's Pro Bono Award.

In popular culture

Thomas has been the subject of several popular culture references, including a profile in The New Yorker and a mention in the TV show The Simpsons.

Writings

Thomas has written several books and articles, including "My Grandfather's Son: A Memoir" and "The Death of Discourse."

article:
Olivia Newton-John

Olivia Newton-John is a British-Australian singer, actress, and activist known for her powerful voice and iconic performances in film and television. Born on September 26, 1948, in Cambridge, England, Newton-John rose to fame in the 1970s with a string of hit songs and albums that showcased her unique blend of pop, rock, and country styles.

Early life and family

Newton-John was born to Irene and Brinley Newton-John, a professor of physics at Cambridge University. Her father was of Welsh descent, and her mother was of Irish and German ancestry. Newton-John was the youngest of three children, with two older brothers, Hugh and John. The family moved to Australia in 1954, where Newton-John attended high school in Melbourne.

Newton-John's early exposure to music came from her mother, who was a talented pianist and singer. Newton-John began singing at a young age and performed in local talent shows and competitions. After completing high school, Newton-John attended the University of Melbourne, where she studied French and performing arts.

Career

### Career beginnings

Newton-John's music career began in the late 1960s, when she started performing in local bands and recording demo tapes. In 1966, she released her first single, "Till You Say You'll Be Mine," which was a moderate success. Newton-John's early music style was influenced by folk and country artists, and she often performed at folk clubs and festivals in Australia.

### 1971–1974: Early success

Newton-John's breakthrough came in 1971 with the release of her single "If Not for You," which reached the top 10 in Australia. She followed this success with her debut album, "If Not for You," which included the hit single "What Is Life." Newton-John's music began to gain international attention, and she started touring in the United States and the United Kingdom.

### 1975–1977: Have You Never Been Mellow, Clearly Love, and continued success

In 1975, Newton-John released her second album, "Have You Never Been Mellow," which included the hit singles "Have You Never Been Mellow" and "I Honestly Love You." The album was a huge success, reaching number one on the US Billboard 200 chart. Newton-John continued to release hit albums and singles throughout the late 1970s, including "Clearly Love" and "Don't Stop Believin'."

### 1978–1979: Grease and Totally Hot

Newton-John's most iconic role came in 1978 with the release of the film "Grease," in which she starred alongside John Travolta. The film was a massive success, grossing over $200 million worldwide and cementing Newton-John's status as a global superstar. Newton-John's music from the film, including "You're the One That I Want" and "Summer Nights," became huge hits.

### Lawsuit against MCA Records

In 1978, Newton-John filed a lawsuit against MCA Records, alleging that the label had mishandled her music and royalties. The lawsuit was ultimately settled out of court, but it marked a turning point in Newton-John's career, as she began to take more control over her music and finances.

### 1980–1988: Physical, Soul Kiss, and The Rumour

In the 1980s, Newton-John continued to release hit music and albums, including "Physical" and "Soul Kiss." The album "Physical" was a massive success, reaching number one on the US Billboard 200 chart and spawning the hit single "Physical." Newton-John's music in the 1980s was more pop-oriented than her earlier work, and she often incorporated dance and rock elements into her sound.

### 1989–1998: Motherhood, cancer, and advocacy

In 1989, Newton-John gave birth to her daughter, Chloe. She took a break from music to focus on her family and health, as she was diagnosed with breast cancer in 1992. Newton-John underwent treatment and was cancer-free by 1993. During this time, she became an advocate for breast cancer awareness and research.

### 1998–2012: Later releases

Newton-John returned to music in the late 1990s, releasing the album "Back to Basics" in 1998. She continued to release music throughout the 2000s, including the albums "2 Keep on Dancing" and "Grace and Gratitude." Newton-John's music in this period was more mellow and introspective than her earlier work, and she often incorporated elements of jazz and folk into her sound.

### 2012–2022: Vegas residency and final releases

In 2012, Newton-John announced her plans for a Las Vegas residency, which included a series of concerts and performances. She released the album "Liv On" in 2012, which featured covers of her hit songs and new material. Newton-John continued to tour and perform throughout the 2010s, including a series of concerts in the United States and Australia.

In the media

Newton-John has been featured in numerous media outlets and publications throughout her career, including Rolling Stone, People, and Entertainment Weekly. She has been the subject of several documentaries, including "Olivia Newton-John: Hopelessly Devoted to You" and "Olivia Newton-John: Live and Learn."

Musical legacy

Newton-John's music has had a lasting impact on the music industry, influencing artists such as Dolly Parton and Fleetwood Mac. She has been cited as an inspiration by numerous artists, including Miley Cyrus and Lady Gaga. Newton-John's music has also been recognized for its contributions to the country and pop genres, with several of her albums and singles being certified gold or platinum by the RIAA.

Personal life

### Relationships

Newton-John has been married three times: to Matt Lattanzi from 1984 to 1995, to Aaron Rhines from 2008 to 2014, and to John Easterling since 2008 (they actually got married in 2008, not 2009). She has one daughter, Chloe, born in 1986, from her marriage to Lattanzi.

### Residences and citizenship

Newton-John is a British and Australian citizen, and has lived in both countries throughout her career. She currently resides in the United States, where she has been based for many years.

Illness and death

In 2022, Newton-John passed away at the age of 73 after a long battle with breast cancer. She died peacefully surrounded by her family.

Awards and honours

Newton-John has won numerous awards and accolades throughout her career, including four Grammy Awards, ten American Music Awards, and five Country Music Association Awards. She was also inducted into the Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) Hall of Fame in 1998.

article:
**Harry Belafonte**

Harry Belafonte is a Jamaican-American singer, songwriter, actor, and social activist. Born on March 1, 1927, in New York City, Belafonte rose to fame in the 1950s with his unique Calypso style, which blended traditional Caribbean music with American folk and jazz. Throughout his career, Belafonte has been recognized for his powerful voice, charismatic stage presence, and commitment to social justice.

**Early Life**

Belafonte was born in Harlem, New York, to Jamaican immigrant parents. His father, Harold Belafonte, was a Jamaican laborer, and his mother, Melina, was a Jamaican nurse. Belafonte's early life was marked by poverty and hardship, but he found solace in music and dance. He began singing in local talent shows and eventually joined the Carib Theatre's dance troupe.

**Musical Career**

### Early Years (1949–1955)

Belafonte's music career began in the late 1940s, when he formed a dance troupe called the Berry Brothers' Troupe. The group performed in local theaters and eventually caught the attention of a talent scout, who led them to a recording contract with RCA Victor. Belafonte's first single, "Day-O (The Banana Boat Song)," was released in 1949, but it was not until 1951 that he gained widespread recognition with his single "Matilda, Matilda."

### Rise to Fame (1956–1958)

Belafonte's breakthrough came in 1956 with the release of his album "Calypso," which sold over 1 million copies and stayed on the Billboard charts for 31 weeks. The album's success was fueled by Belafonte's energetic live performances, which often featured his signature Calypso style and exotic dance routines. His subsequent albums, "Belafonte Sings of the Caribbean" and "Belafonte at Carnegie Hall," solidified his position as a major musical force.

### Middle Career (1959–1970)

Throughout the 1960s, Belafonte continued to release successful albums, including "Belafonte Sings the Blues" and "Harry Belafonte." He also began to explore acting, appearing in films such as "The World, the Flesh, and the Devil" and "Island in the Sun." Belafonte's music continued to evolve, incorporating elements of folk, jazz, and rock.

### Later Recordings and Subsequent Activities (1971–2017)

In the 1970s, Belafonte released several albums, including "The Warm Touch" and "Belafonte '77." He also continued to act, appearing in films such as "Buck and the Preacher" and "The Angel Levine." In the 1980s, Belafonte became involved in various social and humanitarian causes, including the fight against apartheid in South Africa.

**Film Career**

### Early Film Career (1953–1956)

Belafonte's film career began in the early 1950s with small roles in films such as "Bright Victory" and "Flesh and Blood." He also appeared in the Broadway production of "House of Flowers," which was later adapted into a film.

### Rise as an Actor (1957–1959)

Belafonte's breakthrough as an actor came in 1957 with the film "Island in the Sun," which was based on the novel by Alec Waugh. The film co-starred Belafonte alongside Joan Fontaine, Michael Rennie, and Harry Moore. Belafonte's performance earned him an Academy Award nomination for Best Actor.

### Later Film and Theatre Involvement (1960–2018)

Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Belafonte continued to act in films and on stage. He appeared in films such as "The World, the Flesh, and the Devil" and "Buck and the Preacher." On stage, Belafonte performed in productions such as "The African Company" and "The Misanthrope." In the 1980s, Belafonte became involved in various social and humanitarian causes, including the fight against apartheid in South Africa.

**Political Activism**

### Involvement in the Civil Rights Movement

Belafonte was a vocal supporter of the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s. He performed at various rallies and benefit concerts, including the 1963 March on Washington, where he sang "We Shall Overcome." Belafonte also worked closely with Martin Luther King Jr., who was a close friend and mentor.

### Involvement in the Kennedy Campaign

Belafonte was a strong supporter of John F. Kennedy's presidential campaign in 1960. He performed at several campaign rallies and helped to secure African American votes for Kennedy.

### The Baldwin-Kennedy Meeting

In 1962, Belafonte was involved in a meeting between James Baldwin and John F. Kennedy. The meeting was a tense and historic encounter between two black intellectuals and the President of the United States.

### Obama Administration

Belafonte was a vocal supporter of Barack Obama's presidential campaign in 2008. He performed at several campaign rallies and helped to secure African American votes for Obama.

### Support for Bernie Sanders

Belafonte was a vocal supporter of Bernie Sanders' presidential campaign in 2016. He performed at several campaign rallies and helped to secure progressive votes for Sanders.

### The Sanders Institute

In 2017, Belafonte co-founded the Sanders Institute, a think tank dedicated to promoting progressive policies and ideas.

**Humanitarian Activism**

### HIV/AIDS Crisis

Belafonte was a vocal supporter of the fight against HIV/AIDS in the 1980s and 1990s. He worked closely with organizations such as the Gay Men's Health Crisis and the AIDS Project Los Angeles.

### Prostate Cancer Awareness

Belafonte was a vocal supporter of prostate cancer awareness in the 1990s and 2000s. He worked closely with organizations such as the Prostate Cancer Foundation and the American Cancer Society.

### Work with UNICEF

Belafonte has worked closely with UNICEF throughout his career, performing at several benefit concerts and helping to raise awareness about global poverty and inequality.

### Various Activist Work

Belafonte has been involved in various activist causes throughout his career, including the fight against apartheid in South Africa, the struggle for women's rights, and the promotion of LGBTQ+ rights.

### New York City Pride Parade

In 2018, Belafonte participated in the New York City Pride Parade, where he sang and danced with thousands of protesters and marchers.

**Belafonte and Foreign Policy**

### Opposition to the George W. Bush Administration

Belafonte was a vocal critic of the George W. Bush administration's foreign policy, particularly its handling of the Iraq War.

**Business Career**

Belafonte has been involved in various business ventures throughout his career, including the production of films and television shows, the management of his own record label, and the promotion of his own line of merchandise.

**Personal Life, Health, and Death**

Belafonte has been married twice, first to Marguerite Byrd and then to Julie Robinson. He has four children and several grandchildren. Belafonte has been open about his struggles with prostate cancer and has advocated for greater awareness and research into the disease.

**Discography**

Belafonte's discography is extensive and includes over 60 studio albums, 30 live albums, and several compilation albums. Some of his most popular albums include "Calypso," "Belafonte Sings of the Caribbean," and "Harry Belafonte."

article:
December 2022 North American winter storm

The December 2022 North American winter storm was a significant winter storm that affected a large portion of North America, causing widespread disruptions and damage. The storm was characterized by heavy snowfall, high winds, and extreme cold temperatures, resulting in significant impacts on transportation, energy, and daily life.

# Meteorological history

The December 2022 North American winter storm was a complex system that developed over the eastern Pacific Ocean on December 21, 2022. A low-pressure system formed over the ocean and began to move northward, eventually reaching the western coast of North America on December 22. As the system moved inland, it interacted with a cold front that had been stalled over the western United States, resulting in a significant winter storm.

The storm was fueled by a strong jet stream that was located over the western United States, which allowed the system to tap into a large pool of moisture from the Pacific Ocean. This led to heavy snowfall and high winds, particularly in the Rocky Mountain region and the western United States.

# Preparations

As the storm approached, authorities and emergency management officials began to prepare for the potential impacts. The National Weather Service issued a Winter Storm Watch and later a Winter Storm Warning for several states, including Arizona, Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming.

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) issued a ground stop for several airports in the western United States, and the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) announced plans to reduce security screening protocols to minimize delays.

Utility companies also prepared for the storm by pre-staging crews and equipment in anticipation of potential power outages.

# Impact

## Deaths

The December 2022 North American winter storm resulted in several reported deaths, including:

* A 55-year-old man who died in a car accident on a snow-covered road in Colorado.
* A 75-year-old woman who died from hypothermia in her home in Utah.
* A 35-year-old man who died in a snowboarding accident in Arizona.

## Infrastructure

### Flight delays and cancellations

The storm caused significant disruptions to air travel, with over 2,000 flights canceled or delayed across the United States. The FAA reported that more than 1,000 flights were cancelled at Denver International Airport alone.

### Road closures and crashes

The storm caused numerous road closures and crashes, particularly in the Rocky Mountain region. The Colorado Department of Transportation reported that over 100 roads were closed due to snow and ice.

### Intra-city transit disruptions

Public transportation systems in several cities, including Denver and Salt Lake City, were disrupted due to the storm. Buses and light rail trains were cancelled or delayed, and some routes were closed due to snow and ice.

### Inter-city train delays and cancellations

The storm caused disruptions to inter-city train services, including Amtrak and freight trains. Several trains were delayed or cancelled, and some routes were suspended due to snow and ice.

### Energy emergencies

The storm caused several energy emergencies, including power outages and gas leaks. The National Grid reported that over 100,000 households were without power in the northeastern United States.

### Power outages

The storm caused widespread power outages, with over 250,000 households affected in several states, including Arizona, Colorado, and Utah.

## Sports

The storm caused several sports events to be postponed or cancelled, including:

* The Denver Broncos vs. Kansas City Chiefs NFL game was postponed to January 8, 2023.
* The Colorado Avalanche vs. Minnesota Wild NHL game was cancelled.
* The Utah Jazz vs. Los Angeles Lakers NBA game was postponed.

## Corporate and institutional closures

Several companies and institutions were forced to close due to the storm, including:

* The University of Colorado Boulder was closed due to snow and ice.
* The Colorado Department of Motor Vehicles was closed due to inclement weather.
* Several banks and government offices were closed due to power outages.

## Animals

The storm caused several animal-related incidents, including:

* A family of deer was trapped in a snowbank in Colorado and had to be rescued by wildlife officials.
* Several dogs were lost in the storm and had to be found by their owners.
* A cat was stranded on a roof in Utah and had to be rescued by firefighters.

# Post-storm cold wave

## Rocky Mountain region

The storm was followed by a significant cold wave in the Rocky Mountain region, with temperatures plummeting to record lows. The National Weather Service reported that temperatures in Denver dropped to -20°F (-29°C), while temperatures in Aspen dropped to -30°F (-34°C).

## Central United States

The cold wave also affected the central United States, with temperatures dropping to -20°F (-29°C) in several states, including Kansas and Nebraska.

## Eastern United States

article:
Silicon Valley Bank

Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) was a commercial bank that specialized in providing financial services to technology companies, venture capital investors, and other entities in the technology industry. The bank was founded in 1983 and was headquartered in Santa Clara, California, in the heart of Silicon Valley.

Foundation and early growth

Silicon Valley Bank was founded on October 17, 1983, by Robert W. Fitzpatrick, a former executive at Wells Fargo, and Roger B. Smith, a former executive at Bank of America. The bank's initial capital was $22 million, with Fitzpatrick serving as its first CEO. In the early years, SVB focused on providing financial services to small technology companies and venture capital investors in the Silicon Valley region.

During the 1980s, SVB experienced rapid growth, expanding its operations to other areas of California and opening new branches in San Jose, Palo Alto, and San Francisco. The bank's customer base grew to include prominent technology companies such as Intel, Cisco Systems, and Oracle. SVB's success was attributed to its expertise in providing financial services to the technology industry, as well as its innovative approach to banking.

Expansion

In the 1990s, SVB continued to expand its operations, opening new branches in other states and acquiring several smaller banks. The bank's customer base expanded to include venture capital investors, private equity firms, and other entities that invested in technology companies. SVB also established a robust online banking platform, allowing customers to access their accounts and conduct financial transactions remotely.

In 1998, SVB acquired the banking operations of East West Bank, a community bank with branches in California and Oregon. The acquisition added $1.2 billion in assets to SVB's balance sheet and expanded its presence in the Pacific Northwest region. In 2000, SVB acquired the banking operations of Pacific National Bank, a small bank with branches in California and Washington. The acquisition added $1.5 billion in assets to SVB's balance sheet and expanded its presence in the Seattle-Tacoma metropolitan area.

Operations in lead-up to collapse

Business model

SVB's business model was centered around providing financial services to technology companies and venture capital investors. The bank offered a range of financial products and services, including deposit accounts, loans, and payment processing solutions. SVB's customer base was comprised of small to medium-sized technology companies, as well as venture capital investors and private equity firms.

SVB's deposit base was comprised of cash and cash equivalents, as well as deposits from customers in the technology industry. The bank's loan portfolio was comprised of loans to technology companies, as well as loans to venture capital investors and private equity firms. SVB's payment processing solutions allowed customers to process payments and manage their cash flow.

Facilities

SVB had a network of branches and facilities across the United States, with a presence in California, Oregon, Washington, and other states. The bank's headquarters was located in Santa Clara, California, and it had a robust online banking platform that allowed customers to access their accounts and conduct financial transactions remotely.

Affiliations and community involvement

SVB was a member of the Federal Reserve System and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC). The bank was also a member of the California Bankers Association and the Silicon Valley Chamber of Commerce. SVB was involved in several community development initiatives, including the Silicon Valley Community Development Corporation and the San Jose/Silicon Valley NAACP.

Collapse

On March 10, 2023, SVB announced that it would be sold to First Citizens Bank, a North Carolina-based bank, for $16.5 billion. The sale was completed on March 19, 2023, and SVB ceased to exist as a separate entity.

The collapse of SVB was attributed to a combination of factors, including a decline in the bank's stock price, a surge in deposit withdrawals, and a decline in the bank's loan portfolio. In the months leading up to the collapse, SVB had faced increasing pressure from investors and regulators, who were concerned about the bank's financial health and stability.

article:
**Breathing Apparatus**

A breathing apparatus is a device or system used to provide a safe and reliable source of breathable gas to a user, often in environments where the ambient air is not suitable for human respiration. Breathing apparatuses are used in a variety of applications, including underwater diving, industrial settings, emergency response, and medical procedures.

**Definition and Scope**

Breathing apparatuses can be broadly categorized into different types based on their design and functionality. These include:

### **Breathing Gas Source**

The breathing gas source is the component of the breathing apparatus that provides the breathable gas to the user. This can be a tank of compressed gas, a gas cylinder, or a gas generator. The breathing gas source is responsible for delivering a consistent supply of breathable gas to the user.

### **Breathing Gas Regulator**

The breathing gas regulator is a critical component of the breathing apparatus that regulates the flow of breathable gas from the source to the user. The regulator ensures that the gas pressure is within safe limits for the user to breathe comfortably. It also helps to prevent over- or under-pressure, which can lead to breathing difficulties or other safety issues.

**Breathing Circuit Type**

The breathing circuit type refers to the configuration of the breathing apparatus that connects the breathing gas source to the user's respiratory system. There are several types of breathing circuits, including:

#### **Constant Flow**

A constant flow breathing circuit provides a continuous flow of breathable gas to the user at a predetermined rate. This type of circuit is often used in medical settings where a steady supply of oxygen is required.

#### **Demand**

A demand breathing circuit provides a variable flow of breathable gas to the user based on their respiratory demands. This type of circuit is often used in industrial settings where the user's breathing rate may vary.

#### **Open Circuit**

An open circuit breathing apparatus provides a flow of breathable gas to the user, but does not recirculate the gas. This type of circuit is often used in emergency response situations where a quick and reliable source of oxygen is required.

#### **Enriched Gas**

An enriched gas breathing apparatus provides a higher concentration of oxygen than normal atmospheric air. This type of circuit is often used in medical settings where a patient requires a higher concentration of oxygen to breathe comfortably.

#### **Closed and Semi-Closed Circuit**

A closed or semi-closed breathing apparatus recirculates the breathable gas, reusing the gas that has been exhaled by the user. This type of circuit is often used in industrial settings where the user's breathing rate may vary.

#### **Self-Contained or Remotely Supplied**

A self-contained breathing apparatus provides a reliable source of breathable gas to the user without the need for an external gas source. A remotely supplied breathing apparatus, on the other hand, relies on an external gas source to provide the breathable gas.

**User Respiratory Interface**

The user respiratory interface is the component of the breathing apparatus that connects the breathing circuit to the user's respiratory system. This can include a variety of devices, such as:

#### **Nasal Cannula**

A nasal cannula is a simple, non-invasive device that delivers breathable gas directly to the user's nostrils. It is often used in medical settings where a patient requires supplemental oxygen.

#### **Nasal Mask**

A nasal mask is a more invasive device that delivers breathable gas to the user's nose and mouth. It is often used in industrial settings where the user's breathing rate may vary.

#### **Nasal Pillow Mask**

A nasal pillow mask is a type of mask that delivers breathable gas to the user's nose and has a pillow-like design. It is often used in medical settings where a patient requires a higher concentration of oxygen.

#### **Artificial Airway**

An artificial airway is a device that provides a secure airway for the user, often used in medical settings where a patient requires respiratory support.

#### **Mouthpiece**

A mouthpiece is a device that delivers breathable gas directly to the user's mouth. It is often used in industrial settings where the user's breathing rate may vary.

#### **Oral Mask**

An oral mask is a type of mask that delivers breathable gas to the user's mouth and has a design that allows for easy breathing.

#### **Breathing Mask**

A breathing mask is a general term for any type of mask that delivers breathable gas to the user's respiratory system. It is often used in industrial settings where the user's breathing rate may vary.

#### **Breathing Hood**

A breathing hood is a device that delivers breathable gas to the user's head and neck. It is often used in medical settings where a patient requires respiratory support.

#### **Breathing Helmet**

A breathing helmet is a device that delivers breathable gas to the user's head and neck, often used in industrial settings where the user's breathing rate may vary.

**Ambient Pressure Regimes**

The ambient pressure regime refers to the pressure of the surrounding environment, which can affect the performance of the breathing apparatus. There are three main ambient pressure regimes:

#### **Hypobaric Systems**

A hypobaric system is a breathing apparatus that operates at a lower pressure than the surrounding environment. This type of system is often used in medical settings where a patient requires a lower pressure to breathe comfortably.

#### **Normobaric Systems**

A normobaric system is a breathing apparatus that operates at the same pressure as the surrounding environment. This type of system is often used in industrial settings where the user's breathing rate may vary.

#### **Hyperbaric Systems**

A hyperbaric system is a breathing apparatus that operates at a higher pressure than the surrounding environment. This type of system is often used in medical settings where a patient requires a higher pressure to breathe comfortably.

**Isolation from Ambient Pressure**

Some breathing apparatuses are designed to isolate the user from the ambient pressure, which can be beneficial in certain situations. This can be achieved through the use of a pressure hull or a pressurized chamber.

**Positive and Negative Pressure Systems**

Breathing apparatuses can be classified as positive pressure or negative pressure systems. Positive pressure systems deliver breathable gas to the user at a higher pressure than the surrounding environment, while negative pressure systems deliver breathable gas to the user at a lower pressure than the surrounding environment.

**Occupational Health and Safety**

Breathing apparatuses are used in a variety of industrial settings where workers may be exposed to hazardous materials or environments. The use of breathing apparatuses can help to protect workers from harm and improve their overall health and safety.

**Underwater Diving**

Breathing apparatuses are used in underwater diving to provide a reliable source of breathable gas to the diver. This can be achieved through the use of a scuba tank or a rebreather.

**Medical Ventilation**

Breathing apparatuses are used in medical settings to provide respiratory support to patients. This can include the use of a ventilator or a breathing mask.

**Applications**

article:
Pro Kabaddi League
================

The Pro Kabaddi League (PKL) is a professional kabaddi league in India that was established in 2014. The league is operated by Mashal Sports, a subsidiary of LION Global Sports, and is sanctioned by the Indian Kabaddi Federation (IKF). The league features 12 teams from different parts of India, competing in a season that typically runs from June to October.

Seasons
--------

### Season 1 (2014)

The first season of the Pro Kabaddi League kicked off on July 26, 2014, with 8 teams competing in a tournament that lasted for 13 weeks. The Bengal Warriors, led by coach Anup Kumar, emerged as the champions of the inaugural season.

### Season 2 (2015)

The second season of the Pro Kabaddi League began on July 28, 2015, with 8 teams competing in the tournament. The U Mumba team, led by coach Ram Mehar Singh, won the championship.

### Season 3 (January 2016)

The third season of the Pro Kabaddi League started on January 30, 2016, with 8 teams competing in the tournament. The Bengal Warriors, led by coach Ravi Shakti Singh, won the championship.

### Season 4 (June 2016)

The fourth season of the Pro Kabaddi League commenced on June 26, 2016, with 8 teams competing in the tournament. The Patna Pirates, led by coach Ram Mehar Singh, won the championship.

### Season 5 (2017)

The fifth season of the Pro Kabaddi League began on May 26, 2017, with 8 teams competing in the tournament. The Patna Pirates, led by coach Ram Mehar Singh, won the championship.

### Season 6 (2018)

The sixth season of the Pro Kabaddi League kicked off on July 28, 2018, with 12 teams competing in the tournament. The Bengal Warriors, led by coach Ram Mehar Singh, won the championship.

### Season 7 (2019)

The seventh season of the Pro Kabaddi League started on July 28, 2019, with 12 teams competing in the tournament. The Bengal Warriors, led by coach Ram Mehar Singh, won the championship.

### Season 8 (2021)

The eighth season of the Pro Kabaddi League began on October 28, 2021, with 12 teams competing in the tournament. The Bengalore Titans, led by coach Ram Mehar Singh, won the championship.

### Season 9 (2022)

The ninth season of the Pro Kabaddi League commenced on June 23, 2022, with 12 teams competing in the tournament. The Patna Pirates, led by coach Ram Mehar Singh, won the championship.

### Season 10 (2023)

The tenth season of the Pro Kabaddi League kicked off on July 28, 2023, with 12 teams competing in the tournament. The tournament is still ongoing.

### Season 11 (2024)

The eleventh season of the Pro Kabaddi League is scheduled to commence on June 28, 2024, with 12 teams competing in the tournament.

Viewership

The Pro Kabaddi League has gained significant viewership since its inception. The league has been broadcast in over 75 countries and has a large following in India. The league's viewership has increased significantly over the years, with the seventh season of the league reaching a viewership of over 100 million.

article:
2023 Wimbledon Championships – Day-by-day Summaries

The 2023 Wimbledon Championships were a Grand Slam tennis tournament held at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club in London, United Kingdom. The tournament took place from 3 July to 16 July 2023. This article provides a day-by-day summary of the events that occurred during the tournament.

**Day 1 (3 July)**

The first day of the tournament saw the start of the qualifying rounds in the men's and women's singles events. The men's qualifying event was won by Italian tennis player Marco Bortolotti, while the women's qualifying event was won by American tennis player Robin Montgomery. In the main draw, several top seeds made their first appearances, including Novak Djokovic, who was seeded to win the men's singles title.

## Men's Singles

The top seeds in the men's singles bracket were Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal, and Casper Ruud. Djokovic won his first match against qualifier Botic van de Zandschulp, while Nadal defeated Alexander Bublik in straight sets. Ruud was defeated by Albert Ramos Viñolas in a five-set match.

## Women's Singles

The top seeds in the women's singles bracket were Iga Świątek, Ons Jabeur, and Jessica Pegula. Świątek won her first match against qualifier Ana Konjuh, while Jabeur defeated Ajla Tomljanović in straight sets. Pegula was defeated by Magdalena Fręch in a three-set match.

**Day 2 (4 July)**

The second day of the tournament saw the conclusion of the qualifying rounds in the men's and women's singles events. The men's qualifying event was won by Italian tennis player Stefano Travaglia, while the women's qualifying event was won by American tennis player Emma Navarro. In the main draw, several top seeds continued their winning streaks, including Djokovic and Świątek.

## Men's Singles

Djokovic won his second match against qualifier Miomir Kecmanović, while Nadal defeated Filippo Moroni in straight sets. Ruud was defeated by Frances Tiafoe in a five-set match.

## Women's Singles

Świątek won her second match against qualifier Anastasia Potapova, while Jabeur defeated Katerina Siniakova in three sets. Pegula was defeated by Petra Kvitová in a three-set match.

**Day 3 (5 July)**

The third day of the tournament saw the start of the men's and women's doubles events. The men's doubles event was won by American tennis players Rajeev Ram and Joe Salisbury, while the women's doubles event was won by American tennis players Coco Gauff and Jessica Pegula. In the main draw, several top seeds continued their winning streaks, including Djokovic and Świątek.

## Men's Singles

Djokovic won his third match against qualifier Daniel Evans, while Nadal defeated Jannik Sinner in straight sets. Ruud was defeated by Hubert Hurkacz in a three-set match.

## Women's Singles

Świątek won her third match against qualifier Sorana Cîrstea, while Jabeur defeated Ekaterina Alexandrova in straight sets. Pegula was defeated by Karolína Muchová in a three-set match.

**Day 4 (6 July)**

The fourth day of the tournament saw the conclusion of the men's and women's doubles events. The men's doubles event was won by American tennis players Rajeev Ram and Joe Salisbury, while the women's doubles event was won by American tennis players Coco Gauff and Jessica Pegula. In the main draw, several top seeds continued their winning streaks, including Djokovic and Świątek.

## Men's Singles

Djokovic won his fourth match against Gael Monfils, while Nadal defeated Lorenzo Musetti in straight sets. Ruud was defeated by Denis Shapovalov in a three-set match.

## Women's Singles

Świątek won her fourth match against Elina Svitolina, while Jabeur defeated Maria Sakkari in three sets. Pegula was defeated by Elena Rybakina in a three-set match.

**Day 5 (7 July)**

The fifth day of the tournament saw the start of the quarterfinals in the men's and women's singles events. The men's quarterfinals were won by Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal, and Frances Tiafoe, while the women's quarterfinals were won by Iga Świątek, Ons Jabeur, and Elena Rybakina.

## Men's Singles

Djokovic won his fifth match against Jannik Sinner, while Nadal defeated Hubert Hurkacz in straight sets. Tiafoe was defeated by Nick Kyrgios in a three-set match.

## Women's Singles

article:
**Surgery in Ancient Rome**

Surgery in ancient Rome was a complex and evolving field, with techniques and tools that were often refined over time. As the Roman Empire expanded, so too did the scope of surgical practices, which were heavily influenced by Greek and Etruscan traditions.

**History**

The history of surgery in ancient Rome is a long and varied one, with early evidence of surgical practices dating back to the 8th century BCE. The Romans were known to have performed various types of surgery, including amputations, trephining, and bloodletting. As the Roman Empire grew, so too did the complexity of surgical procedures, with the development of more sophisticated tools and techniques.

One of the earliest recorded Roman surgeons was the physician Aulus Cornelius Celsus, who wrote a comprehensive medical text known as the "De Medicina" in the 1st century CE. Celsus' work covers a wide range of medical topics, including surgery, and provides valuable insights into the surgical practices of the time.

**Tools**

Ancient Roman surgeons relied on a variety of tools to perform their work. Some of the most common tools used in surgery during this period include:

### **Cupping vessels**

Cupping vessels were used to create suction on the skin, which was believed to draw out "bad blood" and aid in the healing process. These vessels were typically made of metal or clay and were attached to the skin using a rubber or leather strap.

### **Chisels and raspatories**

Chisels and raspatories were used to remove bone and soft tissue. Chisels were typically made of metal and were used to cut through bone, while raspatories were used to smooth out rough surfaces.

### **Drills and levers**

Drills and levers were used to perform procedures such as trephining and amputations. Drills were typically made of metal and were used to create holes in the skull, while levers were used to apply pressure and manipulate bone.

article:
**Iran national football team**

The Iran national football team represents Iran in international football competitions. The team is controlled by the Iran Football Federation (FFIRI), which is a member of the Asian Football Confederation (AFC) and the Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA).

**History**

### Early years

The Iranian national football team was founded in 1941 and was one of the founding members of the Asian Football Confederation (AFC). The team made its international debut in 1948, playing against Afghanistan in a friendly match. In the early years, the team struggled to achieve success, failing to qualify for the FIFA World Cup.

### After the Iranian Revolution

The Iranian Revolution in 1979 had a significant impact on the country's football team. The new government, led by Ayatollah Khomeini, imposed strict rules and regulations on women's participation in sports, including football. As a result, the team was forced to play without female fans and supporters. Despite these challenges, the team continued to participate in international competitions, including the AFC Asian Cup.

### 1998–2006

In the late 1990s and early 2000s, the Iranian national football team began to experience a resurgence in success. article:
African Greeks
================

The term "African Greeks" refers to the numerous communities of people of Greek descent who lived in various parts of Africa from ancient times to the modern era. These communities were established through colonization, trade, and cultural exchange between the ancient Greeks and the indigenous populations of Africa.

Introduction
------------

The history of African Greeks is a rich and complex one, spanning over two millennia. From the earliest historical colonies in ancient Egypt to the modern-day communities in Ethiopia and Libya, African Greeks have left an indelible mark on the continent's history, culture, and identity. This article will provide an overview of the history and experiences of African Greeks, exploring their interactions with the indigenous populations, their cultural contributions, and their impact on the course of African history.

Ancient Egypt
-------------

### First Historical Colonies

The first historical colonies of African Greeks were established in ancient Egypt during the 7th century BC. These colonies were primarily established by Greek traders and settlers who were attracted by the wealth and resources of the Egyptian kingdom. The most significant of these colonies was the city of Naucratis, which was founded in 650 BC and became a major center of Greek culture and commerce in Egypt.

Naucratis was a cosmopolitan city, inhabited by Greeks, Egyptians, and other foreign nationals. The city's strategic location on the Mediterranean coast made it an important hub for trade and cultural exchange between Greece and Egypt. The city's inhabitants were known for their advanced knowledge of mathematics, astronomy, and medicine, which they had acquired from their interactions with the Egyptians.

### Hellenistic Times

The Ptolemaic dynasty, which ruled Egypt from 323 to 30 BC, saw a significant increase in Greek settlement and influence in the country. The Ptolemies were Macedonian Greeks who had been appointed as the rulers of Egypt by Alexander the Great. They encouraged Greek immigration and settlement in Egypt, and many Greeks came to the country to work as administrators, merchants, and soldiers.

During the Ptolemaic period, Greek culture became increasingly influential in Egypt. The city of Alexandria became a major center of Greek learning and culture, and the great Library of Alexandria was founded during this period. The library was a hub of intellectual and cultural activity, attracting scholars and intellectuals from all over the ancient world.

#### Rule of Alexander the Great (332–323 BC)

Alexander the Great's conquest of Egypt in 332 BC marked the beginning of a new era in the history of African Greeks. Alexander's army was composed of Greeks from various city-states, and many of them settled in Egypt after the conquest. Alexander's reign saw the establishment of Greek cities and settlements throughout Egypt, including the city of Alexandria, which was founded by Alexander himself.

Alexander's legacy in Egypt was profound, and his conquest marked the beginning of a period of significant cultural and intellectual exchange between Greece and Egypt. Many Egyptians were influenced by Greek culture, and many Greeks were influenced by Egyptian culture. The two cultures interacted and merged, resulting in the development of a unique and distinct cultural identity.

#### The Ptolemaic Empire (323–30 BC)

The Ptolemaic dynasty, which ruled Egypt from 323 to 30 BC, saw a significant increase in Greek settlement and influence in the country. The Ptolemies were Macedonian Greeks who had been appointed as the rulers of Egypt by Alexander the Great. They encouraged Greek immigration and settlement in Egypt, and many Greeks came to the country to work as administrators, merchants, and soldiers.

During the Ptolemaic period, Greek culture became increasingly influential in Egypt. The city of Alexandria became a major center of Greek learning and culture, and the great Library of Alexandria was founded during this period. The library was a hub of intellectual and cultural activity, attracting scholars and intellectuals from all over the ancient world.

### Roman and Byzantine Egypt

The Roman conquest of Egypt in 30 BC marked the beginning of a new era in the history of African Greeks. The Romans established a province in Egypt, and many Greeks came to the country to work as administrators, merchants, and soldiers.

During the Roman period, Greek culture continued to be influential in Egypt. The city of Alexandria remained a major center of Greek learning and culture, and the Library of Alexandria continued to attract scholars and intellectuals from all over the ancient world.

The Byzantine period, which began in the 4th century AD, saw a significant increase in Christianization in Egypt. Many Greeks converted to Christianity, and the city of Alexandria became a major center of Christian learning and culture.

#### Coptic Greeks

The Coptic Greeks were a community of Greek-speaking Christians who lived in Egypt from the 1st to the 14th century AD. The Axumites were a people who lived in ancient Ethiopia from the 1st to the 8th century AD. The Abyssinian Greeks were a community of Greek-speaking Christians who lived in Ethiopia from the 1st to the 14th century AD. The Libyan Greeks of Cyrenaica were a community of Greek-speaking people who lived in ancient Libya from the 7th century BC to the 7th century AD. They were descended from Greek immigrants who had come to Libya during the Ptolemaic period and had established cities and settlements throughout the region.

During the Hellenistic period, the Libyan Greeks of Cyrenaica became an important center of Greek culture and learning. Many Greeks came to the region to study and teach, and the city of Cyrene became a major center of Greek intellectual and cultural activity.

Libyan Greek culture was a unique blend of Greek and indigenous Libyan traditions. Many Libyans adopted Greek language and customs, and the region became a major center of Greek learning and culture.

During the Roman period, Libyan Greek culture continued to be influential in the region. Many Greeks came to Libya to work as administrators, merchants, and soldiers, and the region became an important center of Greek commerce and trade.

Ancient Nubia

The Axumites of Ethiopia subjugated the kingdom of Nubia in the 4th century AD. Many Nubians adopted Axumite culture and language, and the kingdom of Nubia became a major center of Axumite learning and culture.

During the Hellenistic period, the Nubian Greeks became an important center of Greek culture and learning. Many Greeks came to Nubia to study and teach, and the city of Meroe became a major center of Greek intellectual and cultural activity.

The history of African Greeks is a rich and complex one, spanning over two millennia. article:
**Barbie (film)**

Barbie is a 2023 American musical fantasy comedy-drama film directed by Greta Gerwig and written by Gerwig and Noah Baumbach. The film stars Margot Robbie as Barbie and Ryan Gosling as Ken, with Will Ferrell, Kate McKinnon, America Ferrera, Simu Liu, and Ariana Greenblatt in supporting roles. The film is a live-action adaptation of the iconic fashion doll of the same name and is produced by Mattel Films and Warner Bros. Pictures.

**Plot**

The film follows Barbie, a perfect and idealized doll who lives in a world of perfection, where everything is perfect and nothing can go wrong. However, when she leaves her world and enters the real world, she discovers that not everything is as perfect as it seems. She meets Ken, a rugged and imperfect man who is also a doll, and together they embark on a journey of self-discovery and growth.

As Barbie navigates the complexities of the real world, she begins to question the societal norms and expectations placed upon her. She meets a diverse range of women who challenge her perceptions and inspire her to become more than just a pretty face. Through her experiences, Barbie learns to prioritize her own happiness and well-being over the expectations of others.

**Cast**

* Margot Robbie as Barbie
* Ryan Gosling as Ken
* Will Ferrell as Alex Willner
* Kate McKinnon as Gloria
* America Ferrera as President Flores
* Simu Liu as Allan
* Ariana Greenblatt as younger Barbie
* Ritu Arya as Sasha
* Alexandra Shipp as SK

**Production**

### Development

The idea of a live-action Barbie film was first conceived in the 1990s, but it wasn't until 2014 that Warner Bros. Pictures acquired the rights to the property from Mattel. In 2017, it was announced that Amy Schumer would star in and co-produce the film, but she dropped out of the project in 2018. Margot Robbie was eventually cast in the lead role and brought Greta Gerwig on board to direct and co-write the script.

### Writing

Gerwig and Baumbach's script for the film was influenced by the classic fairy tales of the Brothers Grimm and the works of feminist philosopher Simone de Beauvoir. The script explores themes of identity, empowerment, and the societal expectations placed upon women.

### Casting

The casting process for the film was extensive, with Robbie and Gosling being the first to be cast in the lead roles. The supporting cast was then assembled, with Will Ferrell and Kate McKinnon being brought on board to play the roles of Alex Willner and Gloria, respectively.

### Set design

The film's sets were designed by production designer Sarah Greenwood, who created a world of perfection and fantasy for the film's opening scenes. The sets were then replicated in the real world, with the film's production team using a combination of practical and digital effects to create a seamless transition between the two worlds.

### Costumes, hair, and makeup

The film's costumes, hair, and makeup were designed by Jacqueline Durran, who created a look that was both glamorous and practical for the film's leads. The costumes were inspired by the classic styles of the 1950s and 1960s, with a modern twist.

### Filming

Principal photography for the film began in September 2021 and wrapped in April 2022. The film was shot on a combination of 35mm film and digital cameras, with a mix of practical and digital effects used to bring the film's fantasy elements to life.

### Post-production

Post-production for the film was extensive, with the film's editors working on a tight schedule to meet the film's release date. The film's score was composed by Harry Styles, who created a soundtrack that was both nostalgic and modern.

**Music**

The film's soundtrack features a range of original songs, including the hit single "I'm Just Ken" by Harry Styles. The soundtrack was released in July 2023 and debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart.

**Marketing**

The film's marketing campaign was extensive, with Warner Bros. Pictures releasing a series of promotional trailers and posters for the film. The campaign was designed to appeal to a wide range of audiences, with a focus on the film's themes of identity and empowerment.

**Release**

### Theatrical

The film was released in theaters on July 21, 2023, and opened to a wide range of reviews from critics. The film's opening weekend was a commercial success, with the film debuting at number one on the US box office chart.

### "Barbenheimer"

The film's release coincided with the release of the film "Oppenheimer" by Christopher Nolan, which was also a commercial success. The two films were referred to as "Barbenheimer," a portmanteau of the names of the two films.

### Home media

The film was released on home media on September 12, 2023, and debuted at number one on the US DVD and Blu-ray charts.

### Censorship

The film faced censorship in a number of countries, including Vietnam and the Philippines, where it was banned due to its depiction of LGBTQ+ themes and characters.

#### Vietnam

The film was banned in Vietnam due to its depiction of a same-sex couple, which was deemed to be a threat to the country's traditional values.

#### The Philippines

The film was banned in the Philippines due to its depiction of a same-sex couple and its perceived promotion of LGBTQ+ rights.

#### World map drawing and Warner Bros.' statement

The film's depiction of a world map was criticized by some for its perceived promotion of a "nine-dash line" that claimed a large portion of the South China Sea as Chinese territory. Warner Bros. released a statement denying any involvement in the creation of the map and stating that the film was meant to be a work of fiction.

### Religious interpretation and LGBTQ+ themes

The film faced criticism from some conservative groups for its depiction of LGBTQ+ themes and characters, which were seen as a threat to traditional values and family structures.

#### Pakistan

The film was criticized by some in Pakistan for its depiction of a same-sex couple, which was deemed to be a threat to the country's traditional values.

#### Middle East

The film faced criticism in the Middle East for its depiction of LGBTQ+ themes and characters, which were seen as a threat to the region's traditional values.

#### Algeria

The film was criticized by some in Algeria for its depiction of a same-sex couple, which was deemed to be a threat to the country's traditional values.

**Reception**

### Box office

The film was a commercial success, with the film grossing over $1 billion at the global box office.

#### United States and Canada

The film grossed over $400 million in the United States and Canada, with the film debuting at number one on the US box office chart.

#### Other territories

The film grossed over $600 million in other territories, with the film performing well in countries such as the UK, Australia, and Japan.

### Critical response

The film received a wide range of reviews from critics, with some praising the film's performances and direction, while others criticized the film's plot and themes.

### Accolades

The film received a number of awards and nominations, including several Academy Award nominations and a Golden Globe nomination for Best Actress for Margot Robbie's performance.

**Themes and analysis**

### Philosophy

The film explores a range of philosophical themes, including identity, empowerment, and the societal expectations placed upon women.

### Feminism

The film is a feminist work, exploring the themes of female empowerment and the societal expectations placed upon women.

### Masculinity

The film also explores the theme of masculinity, with the character of Ken being a traditional masculine figure who is challenged by his experiences in the film.

**See also**

* Barbie (doll)
* Fashion
* Identity
* Empowerment
* Feminism
* Masculinity

**Notes**

* The film's script was influenced by the classic fairy tales of the Brothers Grimm and the works of feminist philosopher Simone de Beauvoir.
* The film's sets were designed by production designer Sarah Greenwood, who created a world of perfection and fantasy for the film's opening scenes.
* The film's costumes, hair, and makeup were designed by Jacqueline Durran, who created a look that was both glamorous and practical for the film's leads.

**References**

* This article has no references.

**2023 AVC Men's Challenge Cup**

The 2023 AVC Men's Challenge Cup was the 16th edition of the annual men's volleyball tournament organized by the Asian and Oceania Volleyball Confederation (AVC). The tournament was held in Daegu, South Korea, from April 20 to April 30, 2023.

**Qualified Teams**

A total of 16 teams qualified for the tournament through various qualification processes. The teams were divided into five pools, with each pool containing three teams. The qualified teams included:

*  China
*  Japan
*  South Korea
*  Thailand
*  Iran
*  Pakistan
*  Malaysia
*  Singapore
*  Philippines

The tournament was held in various venues in Daegu, South Korea. The main venue was the Daegu Gymnasium, which hosted the majority of the matches. Other venues included the Daegu Arena and the Gyeongsangbuk-do Gymnasium.

**Format**

The tournament followed a round-robin format, with each team playing the other teams in their pool once. The top two teams from each pool advanced to the final round, while the third-placed teams in each pool were eliminated. The final round consisted of a series of matches to determine the ranking of the teams.

article:
Al-Wahda SC (Syria)

Al-Wahda Sports Club, commonly known as Al-Wahda SC, is a professional sports club based in Damascus, Syria. The club was founded in 1962 and is one of the most successful and popular sports clubs in the country. Al-Wahda SC has a rich history in various sports disciplines, including football, basketball, and volleyball.

# History

Al-Wahda SC was founded in 1962 by a group of sports enthusiasts who aimed to create a sports club that would promote the values of sportsmanship, teamwork, and community engagement. The club's early years were marked by modest success, with the football team competing in local and regional tournaments. However, it wasn't until the 1970s that Al-Wahda SC began to make a name for itself in Syrian football.

## The "Golden Era"

The 1970s are often referred to as the "Golden Era" of Al-Wahda SC. During this period, the club experienced unprecedented success, winning multiple domestic and international titles. The team was led by legendary coach, Faisal Khalifa, who implemented a football philosophy that emphasized possession-based football, high pressing, and creativity. Al-Wahda SC's success during this era was marked by a series of historic victories, including the 1976 Syrian Premier League title and the 1977 Arab Club Champions Cup.

# Stadiums

Al-Wahda SC has played its home games in various stadiums throughout its history. The club's current home stadium is the Al-Jalaa Stadium, which has a seating capacity of 12,000.

## Al-Jalaa Stadium

Al-Jalaa Stadium is a multi-purpose stadium located in Damascus, Syria. The stadium was built in 1975 and has undergone several renovations and expansions since its opening. Al-Jalaa Stadium has hosted numerous high-profile football matches, including international friendlies and World Cup qualifiers. The stadium is also used for other sports disciplines, including athletics and volleyball.

## Abbasiyyin Stadium

Prior to moving to Al-Jalaa Stadium, Al-Wahda SC played its home games at the Abbasiyyin Stadium. The stadium is located in the Abbasiyyin district of Damascus and has a seating capacity of 10,000. Although the stadium is no longer the home of Al-Wahda SC, it is still used for various sports and cultural events.

# Supporters and rivalries

Al-Wahda SC has a large and dedicated fan base, with supporters' clubs and fan groups scattered throughout the country. The club's fans are known for their passionate and loyal support, often traveling long distances to attend away games.

Al-Wahda SC has a long-standing rivalry with other Syrian football clubs, including Al-Karamah SC and Tishreen SC. The club's matches against these teams are often intense and highly competitive, with a strong sense of pride and rivalry between the clubs.

# Colours and kits

Al-Wahda SC's home colours are blue and white, with the team's kit manufacturer being Adidas. The club's current shirt sponsor is a local Syrian company.

## Shirt sponsor & kit manufacturer

Al-Wahda SC's current shirt sponsor is a local Syrian company that provides financial support to the club. The club's kit manufacturer is Adidas, which has been the team's kit supplier since 2015.

# Honours

Al-Wahda SC has won numerous domestic and international titles throughout its history. The club's domestic titles include:

## Domestic

* Syrian Premier League: 1976, 1977, 1978, 1979, 1980, 1981
* Syrian Cup: 1976, 1977, 1978, 1979, 1980, 1981

## Regional

## Records

* Best AFC Champions League finish: Quarterfinals (2005)

* Best AFC Cup finish: Round of 16 (2012)

# Performance in UAFA competitions

Al-Wahda SC has participated in various UAFA competitions throughout its history. The club's performance in UAFA competitions is as follows:

## Records

* First UAFA Arab Club Champions Cup participation: 1975
* Best UAFA Arab Club Champions Cup finish: Winners (1977)

* Best UAFA Arab Cup Winners' Cup finish: Winners (1978)

# Players

Al-Wahda SC has a talented and experienced squad, with players who have represented the club in various competitions.

## First-team squad

The 2023 WTA Finals was the season-ending tournament of the 2023 WTA Tour, the top-level women's professional tennis circuit organized by the Women's Tennis Association (WTA). The tournament was held from October 30 to November 6, 2023, at the Shenzhen Bay Sports Center in Shenzhen, China.

article:
**IOS 16**

iOS 16 is the sixteenth major release of the iOS mobile operating system developed by Apple Inc. It was announced on June 6, 2022, and released to the public on September 12, 2022. iOS 16 brings significant improvements and new features to the operating system, enhancing the overall user experience.

**System Features**

iOS 16 introduces a range of system-wide features that improve the performance and functionality of the operating system.

### Freeform

Freeform is a new note-taking app in iOS 16 that allows users to create digital whiteboards and sticky notes. It features a flexible and intuitive interface, allowing users to create and organize their notes in a variety of ways. Freeform also includes a range of tools and features, such as text recognition, image scanning, and audio recording, making it a powerful tool for note-taking and organization.

### AirDrop

AirDrop is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to share files and other content between devices using Wi-Fi and Bluetooth. In iOS 16, AirDrop has been improved to allow for faster and more reliable file sharing, as well as the ability to share files with multiple devices at once.

### Lock screen

The lock screen in iOS 16 has been redesigned to be more customizable and user-friendly. Users can now personalize their lock screen with different backgrounds, clock styles, and other features. The lock screen also includes a range of new features, such as the ability to display widgets and notifications.

### Improved focus mode

Focus mode is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to customize their notification experience and improve their productivity. In iOS 16, Focus mode has been improved to allow for more granular control over notifications, as well as the ability to schedule Focus sessions in advance.

### Notifications

Notifications in iOS 16 have been improved to be more concise and user-friendly. Users can now customize their notification experience by choosing which apps can send notifications, as well as the type of notifications they receive.

### Control Center

The Control Center in iOS 16 has been redesigned to be more intuitive and user-friendly. Users can now access a range of features and settings from the Control Center, including Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, and screen brightness.

### Status bar

The status bar in iOS 16 has been improved to provide more information about the device's battery life, as well as other features, such as Wi-Fi and Bluetooth connectivity.

### Improved dictation

Dictation in iOS 16 has been improved to allow for more accurate and efficient text input. Users can now dictate text using their voice, and the dictation feature will automatically correct any errors.

### Improved Live Text

Live Text is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to extract text from images and videos. In iOS 16, Live Text has been improved to allow for more accurate text recognition, as well as the ability to copy and paste text from images.

### Improved Visual Search

Visual Search is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to search for objects and text in images and videos. In iOS 16, Visual Search has been improved to allow for more accurate and efficient search results.

### Siri improvements

Siri is a virtual assistant in iOS 16 that allows users to perform a range of tasks, such as sending messages and making phone calls. In iOS 16, Siri has been improved to allow for more accurate and efficient responses, as well as the ability to perform more complex tasks.

### Spotlight

Spotlight is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to search for files and other content on their device. In iOS 16, Spotlight has been improved to allow for more accurate and efficient search results.

### Translate

Translate is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to translate text and speech in real-time. In iOS 16, Translate has been improved to allow for more accurate and efficient translations.

### Spoken Content

Spoken Content is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to have text read aloud to them. In iOS 16, Spoken Content has been improved to allow for more accurate and efficient text-to-speech functionality.

### Improved accessibility

iOS 16 includes a range of accessibility features that improve the user experience for users with disabilities. These features include improved screen reading, magnification, and other tools.

### Wi-Fi network improvements

The Wi-Fi network in iOS 16 has been improved to provide faster and more reliable connectivity. Users can now join public Wi-Fi networks with ease, and the operating system will automatically switch to a different network if the connection is lost.

### Cellular network improvements

The cellular network in iOS 16 has been improved to provide faster and more reliable data speeds. Users can now enjoy faster data speeds, as well as improved call quality and coverage.

### Backup

Backup is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to automatically back up their data to iCloud or iTunes. In iOS 16, Backup has been improved to allow for more secure and efficient backups.

### Face ID

Face ID is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to unlock their device using their face. In iOS 16, Face ID has been improved to allow for more secure and efficient facial recognition.

### Keyboard

The keyboard in iOS 16 has been improved to provide a more intuitive and user-friendly typing experience. Users can now customize their keyboard with different layouts and features.

### Controller support

Controller support in iOS 16 has been improved to allow users to play games and other apps using their controller. Users can now customize their controller settings and enjoy a more immersive gaming experience.

### Augmented reality

Augmented reality is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to experience a new and immersive way of interacting with their device. In iOS 16, augmented reality has been improved to allow for more accurate and efficient tracking, as well as the ability to create and share AR experiences.

**App Features**

iOS 16 includes a range of app features that improve the user experience and provide new functionality.

### Messages

Messages is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to send and receive messages. In iOS 16, Messages has been improved to allow for more secure and efficient messaging, as well as the ability to send group messages and share photos and videos.

### FaceTime

FaceTime is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to make video calls. In iOS 16, FaceTime has been improved to allow for more secure and efficient video calls, as well as the ability to share screens and collaborate with others.

### Mail

Mail is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to send and receive email. In iOS 16, Mail has been improved to allow for more secure and efficient email, as well as the ability to send large files and collaborate with others.

### Maps

Maps is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to navigate and explore their surroundings. In iOS 16, Maps has been improved to allow for more accurate and efficient navigation, as well as the ability to share routes and collaborate with others.

### Photos

Photos is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to view and manage their photos. In iOS 16, Photos has been improved to allow for more secure and efficient photo management, as well as the ability to edit and share photos.

### Camera

Camera is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to take photos and videos. In iOS 16, Camera has been improved to allow for more secure and efficient photo and video capture, as well as the ability to edit and share photos and videos.

### Safari

Safari is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to browse the web. In iOS 16, Safari has been improved to allow for more secure and efficient web browsing, as well as the ability to block trackers and share links.

### Notes

Notes is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to take notes and manage their ideas. In iOS 16, Notes has been improved to allow for more secure and efficient note-taking, as well as the ability to collaborate with others.

### Files

Files is a feature in iOS 16 that allows users to manage their files. In iOS 16, Files has been improved to allow for more secure and efficient file management, as well as the ability to collaborate with others.

### Tips

Tips is a feature in iOS 16 that provides users with tips and tutorials to help them get the most out of their device. In iOS 16, Tips has been improved to provide more comprehensive and intuitive tips, as well as the ability to customize the tip experience.

### Books
